segments.text: Okay, let's start.
This is Ron Shorn on March 26, 1994, interviewing Andrew T. Young.
So, Andy, for the record, what's your name and the date and place of birth?
Andrew T. Young.
I was born in Canton, Ohio, April 4, 1935.
How did you get interested in astronomy?
interested in astronomy was when I was nine years old, there was a night school course on astronomy given at the local high school.
And my parents decided to go, but they couldn't find a babysitter.
So they dragged me along and told me to sit in the back and keep quiet.
And I was absolutely fascinated with what went on.
The course was taught by Oscar Lee Gustheimer, who was a retired professor of astronomy from Baldwin Wallace College in Berea, Ohio.
And I was absolutely sold on astronomy by Professor Gustheimer.
And from that day on, I intended to become an astronomer.
So what about your schooling?
I went to school in Massillon, Ohio, which is where I grew up.
Never finished high school, but went into college at Oberlin College on a Ford Foundation scholarship.
Graduated from Oberlin in 1955 with a bachelor's degree and went to Harvard for graduate school.
I got my PhD in 61 or 62, I never can remember which.
Okay, what did you get your Ph.D. in?
Astronomy.
What did you do with your thesis?
It was called Stellar Kinematics and Spiral Arms, and I explained the vertex deviation of the velocity ellipsoid by basically a selection effect.
If you form stars in spiral arms in restricted regions of the galaxy, then only stars with particular orbits pass through the solar neighborhood and get observed.
So the younger stars are selectively a subsample of a complete velocity ellipsoidy, kind of a mutilated velocity distribution.
Did that hold up?
Gee, I don't know.
Nobody has used it in years.
All right.
Obviously, that doesn't have very much connection with planetary astronomy.
No, it certainly doesn't.
How did you get interested in planetary astronomy?
Well, I had a small telescope.
Actually, my father bought a skyscope, which was a three and a half inch reflector telescope.
as a result of this night school course.
I actually made an 8-inch telescope of my own while I was in high school.
Planets were something you could look at, so I had some interest in planets, as most amateur astronomers do.
When I got to Harvard as a graduate student, I guess the thing that kind of aimed me in that direction was that Quipple asked me to do a research report on planetary atmospheres.
He was concerned about the origin and evolution of planetary atmospheres and basically made me do a literature search for him.
And so that kind of got me interested in the subject.
And I was also interested in photometry.
I'd gotten interested in the possibilities of photometry from articles in Sky and Telescope and articles in Popular Astronomy that I'd read in high school and college.
And somehow, I can't remember exactly how now, oh, I guess it must have been who probably got me interested in this.
What was your art then, at Harvard?
Yeah, at Harvard.
Let me think.
This was in 1956 or 57.
I read a paper by Harold Johnson on UBD photometry of Mars.
And I guess because of my interest in photometry and my interest in Mars, honestly, I can't remember at this late date how I got into this problem.
But I was concerned about photometry of Mars.
I guess I had looked up the old Cogger and Guthnick articles.
Yeah, that was it.
Looked up the old Cogger and Guthnick articles in which they had a rotational light curve of Mars.
What journal was that in?
That was in the publications of the Berlin Babelsberg Observatory back around 1914, give or take a couple of years.
And interestingly enough, I discovered this past year when I was at the Deutsches Museum in Munich that their instrument has survived and is in the museum there.
You can actually see that historic instrument.
That was the instrument with which the first anything resembling modern photoelectric photometry was actually done.
Well, anyway, they published a rotational light curve of Mars.
And I noticed that Harold Johnson's light curve of Mars was totally different.
Couldn't understand why.
and did an odd thing.
I copied out his numbers.
This was before the days of Xerox machines.
So I copied out his table of numbers, but I didn't want to copy out everything.
So I just copied out the times and the magnitudes and took them home with me to work on and had a copy of the American Ephemeris and Nautical Almanac in those days from which I could
look up and calculate the physical ephemeris of Mars.
And when I did so and calculated central meridians and plotted up his results, I got a light curve that looked just like Carter and Guthnick's and not at all like Johnson's.
And it took me a long time, several days, to realize what had happened.
But when I finally went back and looked at Johnson's table, where he had central meridians, his central meridians were totally different from mine.

And after much cogitation and consulting the tables of the astronomical almanac, I finally realized that what had happened was this, that because Mars rotates through about 350 degrees every day, the central meridians that are listed in the almanac and the physical ephemeris differ by about 10 degrees from one day to the next.
And Johnson and Gardner had interpolated in this 10-degree arc instead of the 350-degree arc.

so i caught harold johnson making a dumb mistake and uh published it in pasp and so offended johnson that i was never able to publish in the astrophysical journal for years but anyway that's that's what got me going in that as a result of that effort uh menzel and the folklore picked me as the guy to take over their uh
and run on a day-to-day basis their planetary photometry project that was sponsored by NASA.
So that's kind of how I got to that stage.
Was that project funded originally by NASA right from the very start?
So far as I know, it was.
Okay, because NASA didn't start until 1958.
Yeah, that's right.
That project started up a couple of years after my paper.
Menzel and I think Kupel might have even been involved in it.
And DeVoe-Klor were, Menzel and DeVoe-Klor at least, were the principal investigators.
And shortly after the thing was funded, or maybe even before it was funded, the Vocaloid went to Texas.
And it was at that point that they needed somebody else to take over the project at Harvard, and I got tapped for that.
I remember Menzel at that meeting.
Which meeting?
meeting where we first met and where the earth shook.
Oh, that's right.
That's the meeting where you were the guy, you and Roger Moore were the representatives from NASA headquarters.
They were the people who were funding you.
You were the guys that were funding me, that's right.
So we got into the great man Menzel's main office.
Into his office, his inner sanctum.
And then we shook hands and you were the first speaker and you were leading on the blackboard.
I was writing something on the blackboard.
And then all of a sudden... Well, all of a sudden what happened was a heavy truck went by, except when you looked out in the street there were no trucks.
And Menzel, as I recall, sat there, timing?
Looking at his watch.
That's right.
That puzzled me that he was looking at his watch.
And after a while, I dawned on people other than Nunzel that it was an earthquake.
It was just timing and periodism.
Yes, yes.
Anyway, I recall him saying the justification for this was that actually there wasn't any precise one third of the planetary planets in existence.
That's absolutely correct.
Which kind of didn't astound me, but it did shake me up a little bit.
Yeah, yeah.
Well, that's because planetary photometry had been in such bad repute for so many years that basically nothing had been done since the work of the 19th century German observers.
Zollner and people like that.
Zollner, and by the way, Zollner's original photometer is also in the Deutsches Museum if you want to see it.
And the world's very first photometer, the very first visual photometer made by Steinhall, is also still in existence in the Deutsches Museum.
It's a wonderful place to go with people.
are interested in the history of photometry.
This isn't directly related to you, but it is directly related to the project.
I have given Zollner more emphasis than he normally gets.
Zollner and Miller.
I read their papers.
Oh, there's an interesting footnote to that, by the way.
I read the papers by Zollner and Miller back when I was a graduate student working on this problem, looking up the past history of the subject of planetary photometry.
And when I got to JPL many years later,

One of the things I retained from that literature search was that the properties of Mercury and the properties of the Moon were very similar and that Mars and indeed all these objects were drastically different from Lambert's law in particular.
And of course that had also been emphasized by Henry Norris Russell in his rediscussion of their observations.
Back in the days when noted astronomers could still do planetary work.
That's right.

background again uh 1910 1916 it's in the app j back there somewhere um and when i got to jpl uh there was this big flap about the mariner 4 pictures which had had uh very low contrast and showed a great deal of light extending out into the sky beyond the limb of mars and it turned out that a student of bruce murray's
had attempted to analyze all this stuff on the basis of the Lambert law.
And, of course, that was because Bruce Murray didn't know anything, and Leighton was a physicist and didn't know anything about planetary photometry.
Well, but you do think Mars is much more like the Moon than Earth.
Yeah, right.
And, of course, I knew that the Moon was drastically different from the Lambert Law.
So I instantly saw that this was a fallacious analysis and went on to demonstrate that all that was, in fact, due to stray light in their Mariner 4 camera.
But at any rate, I remember going down and talking to Layton about this on campus one time and showed him a draft of my paper refuting his work.
And he said, well, you write this as though any fool would know better.
And I said, well, yeah.
Because anybody that was familiar with planetary photometry knew that Lambert's Law was definitely not applicable.
But let me tell you the topper on this.
The topper was that when I went to the Caltech library to look up, to double-check Mueller's work, the pages were all uncut.
No one at Caltech had ever read Mueller's work.
Oh yeah, what I have put in, I guess it's in chapter three, no, chapter two, chapter three, is about Zandler's work and how he,
He knew about Lambert's law, and he did the first accurate with conical prisms photometry.
He had the polarizing photometer.
Yeah, moons, variation, brightness, and faith.
And so immediately, there was not Lambert, and got this completely unexpected result by an unexpected method.
The moon surface was very irregular on a microscopic scale.
So Zalner gets in there, but he certainly was the weirdest looking guy ever.
Oh, yeah?
I've never seen a picture of him.
Okay, so you did this project at Harvard for how long?
Oh, until I left Harvard, and it was taken over by Bill Irvine.
And let's see, I left Harvard in 63, and I started that project, it must have been, I started that project before I got my PhD, so it must have been around 59, I think, that I began working on that.
So roughly 59 to 63.
Okay, and how did you get to go to Texas University?
Harlan Smith invited me to go down.
Actually, Menzel later told me he had told Harlan that I was a good guy and should be invited for a job interview.
Harlan very astutely invited me to go to Texas in the middle of February.
He was well known for that tactic.
Yeah, right.
It worked in my case.
I certainly was easily seduced to a warmer climate.
Oh, by the way, I forgot to mention at the beginning, this interview is being taped at the Shorn Ranch in Brazos County, Texas.
All right.
OK, so you accepted.
So I immediately accepted Harlan's invitation and left.
So when did you actually begin at UT?
I began at UT.
I've got to make a correction here, Ron.
My memory had failed me there for a minute.
I actually left that planetary technology project a couple of years earlier, 61 or 62, because I had been offered a postdoc position by ORT.
And because of family complications, I was never able to accept that.
But I had resigned my position.
And Bill Irvine took that over a year or so before I went to Texas.
So what did you do between the time you left that project?
I was working on another solar system project that was run by Hector Angrio at Harvard's Smithsonian.
He was making 10 micron thermal infrared measurements of the moon.
And there were about six people working on that.
There was Hector, who was in charge of the project and was a very good engineer.
He had designed the instrument that we used.
There was an electronics technician who built amplifiers for the instrument.
There was a mechanical engineer that did the precise machining that was required.
And there were a couple of secretaries and data reducers.
And I was the astronomer.
I was the observer on that.
Back in the days when astronomers actually observed?
I'll say astronomers actually observed.
I had the privilege, Paul, on that project
of observing at the Newtonian focus of the Radcliffe reflector when it was still outside Pretoria on the coldest night ever recorded in Pretoria.
I was up there freezing and relaying temperatures from the thermometer we had at the eyepiece, and Thackeray, the observatory director, was saying to Hector, he must be reading the thermometer wrong.
It never gets that cold here.
How cold was it?
It was something like 20 degrees.
It was well below freezing.
Tell me something about, well, there's two questions.
One is about Menzo, who I can interview.
And then we'll get on to a more general question.
But first of all, Menzo had one of the early, when he was out of grad school or something, he did an estimate of Martian surface pressure.
Oh, did he?
I wasn't aware of that.
Well, back in 1926, Menzo had published an article
using visual photographic albedo observations.
Okay, so that must have been why Menzel was interested in photometry of Mars as well.
Right, and an upper limit for the surface pressure of Mars, which it turns out was correct, and in fact was below the value quoted by Gerard de Bacallure in his famous book, Physics of the Planet.
That's interesting.
I didn't know that.
And there is a story that I have heard
that I can't document, to the effect that Menzel was taken aside by somebody at Harvard, presumably the great man himself.

Carlos Shackley told a young man, if you want to keep a job in astronomy, if you want to feature in this field, that you should get out of this nonsense of planetary astronomy and get into real astronomy.
Have you heard anything about that?
I haven't heard that story, or at least I don't remember hearing that story, but it sounds entirely credible.
I can't interview Menzel.
What kind of a guy was he?
Well, at the time I was a graduate student, Menzel was a terrible stuffed shirt.
He was pompous.
He was not keeping up with current events scientifically.
I remember there was a notorious occasion.
in which Armin Deutsch had done a spherical harmonic analysis of magnetic fields on some rotating magnetic star.
And at the end of his talk, this was at a AAS meeting that was actually held in Cambridge,
At the end of his talk, Menzel stood up and said, well, have you considered using spherical harmonics?
And Deutsch looked absolutely baffled and said, but I thought that's what I did.
That was kind of a typical Menzel performance.
He was just out of it and over the hill by then.
And strangely enough, as a result of this planetary photometry project,
One of the things that came out was a really good measurement of the albedo of Venus as a function of wavelength, which really showed quantitatively the amount of absorption in the ultraviolet.
And shortly before he died, I ran into Menzel at a
An IAU symposium in Torun, Poland.
That would have been in 73 or 74.
Copernicus.
The Copernicus thing, yeah.
And Menzel had the temerity to say to me, I've never believed in this ultraviolet absorber on VS.
It looks white to me.
I was just speechless.
I didn't know what to say because it was his own project that had quantitatively shown the existence of the ultraviolet absorber that had been previously inferred, of course, from W.H.
Wright's photographs and other such measurements much earlier.
You had Whipple, who certainly was interested in the solar system.
Yeah, Whipple was a good guy to work for.
And you had Menzel, who had been and now was interested in the solar system.
Yeah, had an interest, but he was full of useless information.
One thing he did, for example, on Venus was to imagine that the high temperature measured for Venus was due to an enormous electron density in its ionosphere.
So he sent me off on a wild goose chase to learn about ionospheres.
Oh, man.
I looked that stuff up.
I quickly found he was off by many orders of magnitude.
And that taught me just to ignore anything that Menzel suggested after that.
And he quickly forgot these suggestions for the most part.
You could sort of nod and smile and then go off and ignore them.
But there's other people who were there at the same time, like Imbrow.
Yes.
And also there was Whipple and JL and Hynek and those people because they had the, what was it, the IGY?
Oh, that was the Moonwatch business that Smithsonian was running.
Well, that means that at least at that time, they were willing to take money to do research on the solar system, which, as I gather,
Let me tell you something about Quipple's connection in this.
Quipple got into this through the meteor program.
Harvard had a long-standing meteor program that involved Quipple because of his interest in meteors and comets and meteoroids as fragments of comets and so on.
Luigi Acchia, I'm not quite sure how he got into it.
And there were several people at Harvard who were supported on the media program.
They also developed the Super Schmidt cameras.

The Super Schmidt cameras were developed by Baker himself, who was associated, he was some kind of an associate on the Harvard staff, not paid by Harvard, but had an office and showed up about once a month.

And so Whipple's interest in the upper atmosphere densities, or I shouldn't say his interest, but his authority as an expert on upper atmosphere densities got him called in very early, before even there was a NASA, there was a thing called the rocket panel.
Remember the rocket panel?
That was set up to decide how to use scientifically the V2 rockets that have been captured at the end of World War II.
And later, when the IGY came along, that had its name expanded, and it became the Rocket and Satellite Panel.
And people remained a member of it when it was the Rocket and Satellite Panel.
So he was there on that panel as an expert on upper atmosphere densities, which he had gotten through the Meteor Project.
And so that was how this business of satellite tracking, I'm sure how he got the connection there.
But still, for Volker, there were many great
It was considered demeaning to work for NSA or prostituting yourself.
It was dirty money, and the planetary work was a dead end because it had all been done by Adams and Dutton and Polarges.
Did you find that at Harvard?
Oh, yes.
You certainly got that attitude.
And I remember when Kuiper came and talked to us,
He mentioned that he had received criticism for doing that Lunar Atlas project.
Which was done with Air Force One.
That's right.
But he had been criticized for doing that instead of doing honest astronomy, you know, decent astronomy.
Because Piper had started out doing things like the effective temperature scale.
He had a paper in the 1930s, 36-ish, as I recall, late 30s sometime.
in which he had done a good recalibration of the effective temperature scale.
It started out in stellar astronomy.
Then he went into close binaries and mass ratios, which led him into a mass ratio association plan between Sun and Jupiter.
Did you get the feeling that this new planetary and solar system work at second rate was general?
It certainly was, yeah.
Did Harvard take any money from the Air Force?
Harvard had a lot of Air Force money, and the reason was that the Air Force Bedford Laboratories, as they were called.
Well, it was originally the Air Force Cambridge Research Laboratories, and they moved out to Bedford.
But the Air Force labs were nearby, and people at Harvard Observatory had connections there.
And so there were a lot of airport-sponsored projects.

For example, I was hired one summer to try to make sense of a release of a barium cloud or something like that from, maybe it was nitric oxide, but anyway, something that was released from a rocket in the upper atmosphere.
They'd used the Super Schmitz to take photographs of it.
They wanted to track the motion.
get upper atmosphere winds, that kind of stuff.
So yeah, there was a lot of that kind of stuff going on at Harvard.
There was also Office of Naval Research, but that was done for more classical type of stellar astronomical studies.
Gee, there was a lot of ONR work, but I was never employed on one of the ONR programs.
So I can't really tell you, but I know people talked about ONR.
The ONR got involved, you remember, early in radio astronomy.
They had that radio dish on top of their building in Washington someplace.
They also built the radio telescope at the University of Illinois.
Oh, did they?
Okay.
So because one of the first places involved in radio astronomy was Harvard, there were connections there, I guess.
Bach, you remember, was one of the people who was involved in radio astronomy.
He was 21 centimeter long.
And because of Ewan and Purcell's work in...
the co-discovery of the 21 centimeter line there at Harvard.
That was why radio astronomy got an early start at Harvard earlier than many other places.

In fact, it was while I was a graduate student that they finally decided about my third or fourth year in graduate school that they were going to give a different set of prelim exams to the radio astronomers because they needed a sufficiently different background than the optical astronomers.
Instead of giving the same set of questions to everybody, they were going to have a two-track system.
When NSA was first born, that was, let's see, 59, I guess.
58, probably, because it was right after school.
What was the attitude by then?
You got your Ph.D.
I forgot.
I got my Ph.D. in 61 or 62, so I was still a graduate student.
But what were the comments you heard about NESA?
Because they were coming with a lot of money, space research, solar system research.
What sort of comments did you hear from science?
Oh, gosh.
There wasn't an awful lot of reaction to it at first.
The main interest around Harvard was in the satellite tracking program.
Huppel and Hynek were the guys that were the chief motivators behind that.
I guess the bigger scandal at the time was the fight over moving the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory from Washington to Cambridge.
because it had always been associated with the Smithsonian Institution of Washington in the era of Charles Greeley Abbott.
And Whipple and other people who were interested in solar activity had been very critical of Abbott's work.
And the whole thing was, when Whipple was made the new director, the whole thing was just picked up and moved to Harvard and Abbott's stuff and the whole
Solar constant measurement program, all that stuff was done.
So it was a major change in direction.
And I think that was more of a notorious cause than the creation of NASA, which wasn't viewed as being terribly important at first, at least not by the people at Harvard.
As I say, we got some grants from NASA, and it was regarded as
kind of just another funding agency like the Air Force.
Well, when they started up, of course, things were much more informal and less bureaucratic than they are today
When they started up, the bureaucracy was not so multilevel, and the oversight of contracts was much more simplified.
I used to send in quarterly reports about a page long that were hardly more than a letter, and we'd have an annual report that would be maybe five or six pages long, but nothing terribly big.
I had a secretary that did
some of the financial accounting that was required.
All that stuff had to be done in-house.
There weren't these grant handling subsidiaries that organizations have these days.
And so it was all kept to the level where individual scientists could manage it.
So it was quite tolerable at that time in the 60s.
It gradually grew more and more top-heavy as time went on.
Now, since I've been on both sides of this issue, I can ask you this with equal subjectivity at both ends.
All right.

Back in the early days, there was a lot of comment among scientists, the managers, the people who were coming monitoring contracts from the United States, were incompetent and didn't know any science.
And they just had to put up with these fools.
Do you think that was the widespread attitude?
I do think so.
I guess there was criticism of NASA really fairly early on that it had staffed its organization with people swept up off the street rather than with competent scientists.
There wasn't an awful lot of scientific expertise at NASA headquarters.
As I say, we regarded NASA as kind of similar to NASA.
the Air Force in terms of being a funding agency.
We didn't have any impression that the NASA guys had much astronomical background.
And in fact, as I recall, I wrote a nasty letter to the editor of science back in, oh goodness, when was it?
It must have been about that time, 59, 60, 61, somewhere in there, about the time I got my PhD, complaining about
people talking about things outside low Earth orbit as deep space.
And I was called on the carpet by Menzel for offending these granting agencies and telling me that I should clear anything like that that went out with him before I sent it out.
I guess you should go back and read what I wrote in that letter to science if you can dig it up.
Okay, so you went to Texas in what year?
63, yeah.
Was it 63 or was it 65?
Let me think now.
You were at Harvard in either 63 or 64 whenever that earthquake took place.
Okay, so it must have been 65 when I was in Texas for two years.
Must have gone in 65 and left in 67.
Yeah, that would be right.
Went to Texas in 65.
I said 63 earlier, but that was wrong.
OK. Now, at Texas, the director at that time was Harlan J. Smith.
Right.
What kind of a guy was Harlan?
Harlan was an interesting guy.
He radiated sincerity, which made him a master of grantsmanship.
He unfortunately didn't radiate scientific competence, or at least not to me.
I was appalled at some of the things he did.
But he was enthusiastic, and I'm sure he believed everything he said.
The sincerity was not a fake.
And he was very good at building up the department there, and argued continually that they had to make the place big before they could make it good.
And I had just the opposite view, which contributed to my leaving.
I didn't like the way things were going.
But Harlem was entirely pleasant, but not real savvy as far as science goes, I would say.
Now, DFT was unusual in that it was possible to get telescope time from a major telescope, 82-inch.
to do work on the planets.
That's right.
Was that due to Harlan?
That was probably DeVocalor's influence, I would guess.
I think Harlan respected GDV very considerably, and I think it was probably DeVocalor who pushed the planetary aspect there.
Of course, after the 107 inch was built, that was specifically for the purpose of planetary stuff, and that was part of
around Zempire building effort, and so he was happy to follow the NASA money in that direction.
But there was some planetary work done with smaller telescopes, in particular a lot done with the 82-inch.
Well, for a long time, that was the only large telescope in the world that devoted a significant fraction of its time to planetary work.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
You remember Toby Owen's story when he was at Caltech for a semester.
Did you talk to Toby Owen about this?
I saw him in October, but we didn't have time.
Okay, you need to ask him about this.
He spent either a semester or a year, I forget which, at Caltech.
And he wanted to get some, I think, twilight time to observe Venus or Mars or something like that.
And they wouldn't give him any 200-inch time to look at anything planetary.
But then, what the heck was it?
He put in a proposal to observe a comet or something like that.
And they granted him time for that, which surprised him.
And he was very keenly aware of the anti-solar system bias.

And the only way he could understand getting time to observe this comet was he figured the guys at Caltech must figure that stars come from comets because they didn't see what the connection was with planets, obviously.
Okay, where did you go from Texas?
From Texas, I went for a brief time to the Aerospace Corporation in El Segundo, and then after about six months to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena.
At the Aerospace, where I was taking the night shift on the millimeter radio telescope at the time, which is why I seldom saw you there, you were supposed to do solar astronomy.
That's right.
Aerospace had the solar observatory, which was
at Upper Van Norman Reservoir in Sylmar, I believe it was.
And they had had a program of photographing the solar granulation for several years with a small telescope on Kodak 649 film, which was a super high resolution film.
The grains, in fact, were so small that they were actually smaller on the average than the penetration depth of
optical radiation into silver.
So when you hold up these negatives, they look greenish by transmitted light.
That's how small the grain size was.
And they were trying to understand seeing at their site, which was sometimes good and sometimes bad.
And I had done some work on simulation and atmospheric turbulence, and I think that was what they were interested in there.
Okay, so then where did you go and why to JPL?
I went to JPL and got a job at JPL working with, what the heck was that group called?
I can't remember.
What year was it?
That would have been 68, I guess.
And what was that group doing in particular?
The group I was with was involved in the design of the Mariner cameras for Mariner 6 and 7.
And I had been there for, oh, probably a couple of months, finishing up some papers I'd been working on earlier.
And one day my boss came by and said, you should be going to these Tuesday morning meetings.
I said, what Tuesday morning meetings?
Well, it turned out these Tuesday morning meetings were the
the Yerner 6 and 7, I guess it was called Yerner 67 at that time, because that was the year, imaging team meeting.
And that was Robert Layton, Bruce Murray, a bunch of JPL engineers.
There'd be about a thousand people in the room, typically.
And so I went to those meetings, and it quickly became apparent that one of the things they were concerned about was getting the exposure correct.
for this next round of Mariner photographs of Mars, TV pictures of Mars.
And since I'd had some experience with planetary photometry, they tapped me to look into the problem.
They had a very strange algorithm built into their camera, which, because the camera scans slowly across the disk of the planet at a fixed phase angle, we just called it a fixed angle,
as the spacecraft swept by, they would sample a little piece of the leading edge of one frame to guess what the exposure should be for the next frame.
However, this was complicated by the fact that all our frames were taken with red and green filters.
And there was some funny thing.
They had originally planned to have a third filter in the system, a blue filter or something like that, and then decided not to, to reduce the data to be transmitted back or something like that.
So there'd be a red and a green pair and another red and a green pair and another red and a green pair and gaps in between the pairs.
And so I made a little simulation program to predict for various reasonable photometric functions, not Lambert, what was going on.
It was as a result of that project that I dug back into the
We ordered four stops that Leighton and Murray had done and showed it was wrong.
Actually, it was what Murray's graduate student had done that was wrong.
I don't think Leighton and Murray really knew what was going on.
OK. How long did you stay at JPL?
Let's see.
I left JPL in, what was it, 73?
OK.
What did you do at JPL besides the photometric stuff?
Well, I was involved in that business, and they sort of, after the fact, packed me onto their TV team there from Mariner 6 and 7.
And then the next project was the Mariner 69 project, which was Mariners 8 and 9.
Mariner 8 wound up at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean, but Mariner 9 made it to Mars.
So I was on that TV team from the inception of it.
And I was also involved in some other stuff.
Mariner 10 I was peripherally involved in.
I was the guy who told them they needed to take UV pictures of Venus to see what the cloud features looked like.
If it hadn't have been for me, they might not have thought of that.
It was certainly at my insistence that they had to get into the UV, that they planned UV capabilities for the camera there.
Then when Viking came along, I was on the Viking lander team.
and was involved in that.
That was a funny thing, because I got into that after the fact.
The Viking lander team, there had been a pre, you know, there's always these, before the project exists, there's the group put together to plan for it.

And there had been this lander camera team that had written an impossible set of specifications where they wanted to focus from three feet to infinity with no changes in focus or at most one focus step or something like that.
And they wanted a thousand to one signal to noise ratio.
And they wanted to scan at a certain rate so that you could only look at a piece of the scene for a tenth of a millisecond.
And all these requirements were mutually exclusive.
If you just look at the laws of physics, in order to get the angular resolution, they demanded you have to add a lens a certain size.
In order to get the lens that big, you had to have something like five or six focus steps between

a meter and infinity and besides if you made the lens small enough that you could focus from here to there with only one or two focus steps then you didn't get enough photons in to meet their signal to noise requirement it was all a hodgepodge and i just i i somehow came across this memo with their design statement as to what it was to do realized that this contradicted the laws of physics wrote a memo pointing this out and got stuck on that team for a while
Where did you go after JPL?
After JPL, let's see, I must have gone here to Texas A&M, mustn't I?
Yeah.
And what did you do at Texas A&M?
At Texas A&M, well, I survived on my Viking money for a while.
I did some part-time teaching.
Had several proposals turned down by the National Science Foundation.
One day I got a phone call from...
I got a phone call from somebody at NASA headquarters saying, somebody was saying, why aren't there any proposals from Andy Young?
So they asked me to send them a proposal, and I sent them a proposal on something, which I can no longer recall.
which was funded.

And George Catawar and I did a lot of work in which we looked at the brightness distribution over the disk of Mars and Venus in various spacecraft pictures and studied balloon darkening and the scattering properties of the atmospheres and stuff like that.
Still continuing basic planetary photometric stuff and doing on the side a certain amount of planetary spectroscopy.
And then where did you go from there?
To San Diego State.
And where you still are.
Well, sort of.
And when did that happen?
That would have been 80 or something like that.
It was right at the beginning of 81.
And Louise had put in for a National Research Council
travel grant to go and work with the people at the Space Research Institute in Moscow on the Venera spectra of Venus.
And we hadn't had time to move in even in San Diego before it was time to go off and pick that up.
So we just locked up the house and went off to Moscow for three months.
And that worked out okay.
We had a very interesting time in Moscow working with Moroz and his co-workers and found they had a very sharp group there.
Very clever people.
And what have you been doing lately?
Lately?
Well... After you came back from Moscow.
Okay.
After I came back from Moscow, I continued to have some support from NASA for a few years.
That eventually petered out and I wasn't able to resuscitate it.
But about the time that died, I got a grant
from NSF, which I've been living on for the past three or four years, in stellar photometry, which was my interest for many years also, in parallel with planetary photometry.
And in, I remember it was, 89?
Yes, 89, I became the vice president of Commission 25, which is stellar photometry and polarimetry.
and then became the president of the succeeding meeting in Buenos Aires.
So I'm currently coordinating the activities of IAU Commission 25 on stellar photometry.
So I've kind of gotten out of the planetary business as a result.
Do you think that the real quote-unquote astronomers still look down on planetary studies, solar system studies?
Not as much as they used to for several reasons.

One is that people have begun to appreciate the connection between planets and the process of star formation and to realize that planetary systems are a useful link in understanding the star formation process, questions of chemical evolution in the galaxy and things of that sort.
This also is a link between things like the giant molecular clouds

and stellar astronomy and these objects also play an important dynamical part in the rotation of galaxies so i think the field has become more unified with the rest of astronomy and people see the interconnections of these fields more than they used to i think it's less compartmentalized in a way even though things have become more specialized in recent years
